Parameters.Conditions: FAO ecological zone: Temperate mountain system; vegetation type: Trees, conifer (needleleaf) evergreen; species/forest composition: Pinus contorta-93%, Picea engelmanni-3%, Abies lasiocarpa-3%; stand age: 98
Region.Regional.conditions: country: Canada; state/province/region: Alberta; geographic coordinates: 50.27, -114.59; elevation: 1903 m; continent: North America; Koeppen climate zone: Dfc; mean annual temperature: 0.8 degrees C; annual precipitation: 626 mm yr-1
Other.Properties: ForC site: Alberta AB10 (ID#: 23); ForC plot: Pinus contorta-93%, Picea engelmanni-3%, Abies lasiocarpa-3% (ID#: 22); ForC measurement ID: 140; Date of Measurement: 1984; plot size: 0.1 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1886; variable description: Total live aboveground biomass.
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Other.Properties: ForC site: Ontario ON2 (ID#: 1363); ForC plot: Pinus banksiana-58%, Picea mariana-41%, Populus tremuloides-1% (ID#: 1728); ForC measurement ID: 10381; Date of Measurement: 2006; plot size: 0.12 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1871; variable description: Total live aboveground biomass.
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Other.Properties: ForC site: Ontario ON9 (ID#: 1370); ForC plot: Pinus banksiana-85%, Betula papyrifera-9%, Populus tremuloides-6%, Picea mariana-1% (ID#: 1735); ForC measurement ID: 10402; Date of Measurement: 2004; plot size: 0.12 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1895; variable description: Total live aboveground biomass.
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Region.Regional.conditions: country: Canada; state/province/region: Saskatchewan; geographic coordinates: 54.05, -105.48; elevation: 1353 m; continent: North America; Koeppen climate zone: Dfc; mean annual temperature: -0.6 degrees C; annual precipitation: 475 mm yr-1
Other.Properties: ForC site: Saskatchewan SK16 (ID#: 1621); ForC plot: Picea glauca-54%, Populus tremuloides-45%, Populus balsamifera-1% (ID#: 2141); ForC measurement ID: 13161; Date of Measurement: 1980; plot size: 0.08 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1892; variable description: Total live aboveground biomass.
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Other.Properties: ForC site: Saskatchewan SK19 (ID#: 1624); ForC plot: Picea glauca-61%, Populus balsamifera-37%, Picea mariana-3% (ID#: 2144); ForC measurement ID: 13171; Date of Measurement: 1999; plot size: 0.08 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1874; variable description: Total live aboveground biomass.
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Other.Properties: ForC site: Saskatchewan SK26 (ID#: 1632); ForC plot: Populus tremuloides-57%, Picea glauca-42%, Abies balsamifera-1% (ID#: 2152); ForC measurement ID: 13203; Date of Measurement: 1996; plot size: 0.08 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1887; variable description: Total live aboveground biomass.
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.

Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
Comments.from.Data.Provider: confidence notes: 95%CI is NA because only 1 plot was measured; biomass allometry source: Lambert MC, Ung CH, Raulier F (2005) Canadian national tree aboveground biomass equations. Region.Regional.conditions: country: Canada; state/province/region: Quebec; geographic coordinates: 48.83, -75.1; elevation: 452 m; continent: North America; Koeppen climate zone: Dfc; mean annual temperature: 0.2 degrees C; annual precipitation: 1006 mm yr-1
Other.Properties: ForC site: Quebec QC9 (ID#: 1506); ForC plot: Picea mariana-100% (ID#: 1968); ForC measurement ID: 49088; Date of Measurement: 1973-1992; plot size: 0.04 ha; disturbance type: No severe disturbance since 1886; variable description: Net increment (accounting for gains + losses) in live aboveground biomass
Full.Technical.Reference: Ma, Z., Peng, C., Zhu, Q., Chen, H., Yu, G., Li, W., ... Zhang, W. (2012). Regional drought-induced reduction in the biomass carbon sink of Canada's boreal forests. Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, 109(7), 2423-2427. doi:10.1073/pnas.1111576109
Abstract.in.English: The boreal forests, identified as a critical 'tipping element' of the Earth's climate system, play a critical role in the global carbon budget. Recent findings have suggested that terrestrial carbon sinks in northern high-latitude regions are weakening, but there has been little observational evidence to support the idea of a reduction of carbon sinks in northern terrestrial ecosystems. Here, we estimated changes in the biomass carbon sink of natural stands throughout Canada's boreal forests using data from long-term forest permanent sampling plots. We found that in recent decades, the rate of biomass change decreased significantly in western Canada (Alberta, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba), but there was no significant trend for eastern Canada (Ontario and Quebec). Our results revealed that recent climate change, and especially drought-induced water stress, is the dominant cause of the observed reduction in the biomass carbon sink, suggesting that western Canada's boreal forests may become net carbon sources if the climate change-induced droughts continue to intensify.
